content.description: This is on the lower terrace of the park, very visible just as you enter the park. The route is to the right of the face. The start is a running dyno to a large flat edge. Climb the rest of the holds up.
content.protection: I'd place a pad to the left of most of the route, as the initial dyno may have you swinging...and falling.
content.location: Just to the right as you enter the park. The color of the rock is bright yellow, very hard to miss.

content.description: Start in the crack in the corner right of "When in Doubt".   Do a few nifty moves to avoid the dyno start of "When in Doubt" and finish the same way
content.protection: Is over a pile of mulch, but a pad wouldn't hurt.
content.location: Right of "When in Doubt", only crack around.

content.description: Start from opposing jugs, go straight up to the crack under the small roof

content.location: Obviously, look for the tree )Â

content.description: Easy holds into a thin crack traverse, into a reaching crux over the roof, then another crack traverse to another feature set to the left, then up to the top with small chossy knobs -- this route is crimp city boulder, but extended into the finger crack traverse etc.
content.location: flattest and blankest section of the upper quarry, very near the leftmost side of the main wall

content.description: After the starting ledge (green line), the only holds "on" for the starting wall are the crimp (purple arrow) and the second ledge (purple line) near the large diagonal crack. The next hand is a mantle off the left face on the upper section of the right wall (yellow). The middle section of the right wall is off (red lines). Using small crimps on the upper section, find feet below on the lower section and traverse across. Gain the upper ledge (blue tick). Top is at the white carat.
content.protection: One pad, maybe two, below the right wall
content.location: Two hands on the obvious low ledge left of the diagonal crack, left of "Parvus"

content.description: Hand crack that turns into an off-width halfway up, not vertical so a fall is dangerous, bad feet the whole way but solid crack holds
content.location: Far right side of upper quarry, tucked behind the main wall on a corner turned rightward

content.description: An old drill scar. Starts with an undercling directly below where the scar disappears. Once up a little higher all hands and feet are inside or directly along the edge of the scar, other than the final feet, which are 2 nice ledges well outside the scar. In the lower portion of the scar there is a crack along the back that offers possible hands and good feet.
content.protection: Pad, but the landing is fairly flat
content.location: Near the middle of the upper terrace. Look along the cliff for the most obvious scar, although there are several. There is a group of boulders (too small to climb) near the bottom. See pictures

content.description: SDS on the nice ledge, climb straight up avoiding the temptation to use the drill scar/crack to your left. Top out at the two nice pockets.
content.location: Immediately to the left of touch the tree

content.description: "Parvus" lies just to the left of "When in doubt..." Start holding on to the left facing "crack," then reach up to the sloper that can really only be held like an undercling. Next handhold is a crimp, and finish on a horizontal edge.
content.protection: I'd place the pad just beneath you, as you mostly climb straight up.
content.location: "Parvus" is just to the left of "When in doubt..." This means it is on the left side of the first visible rock face you see as you enter. It goes straight up. Read the description for the moves. Also, see pictures.

content.description: Mini-approach to the main crack, main crack runs up 2/3 the height of the wall, offwidth but solid rock, deep and bad feet all the way to the top-out
content.location: leftmost corner of the top quarry

content.description: Start with one hand in a pocket and one in a single grip before following a quick route ending in a two handed grip on an overhanging ledge to the right of the start.
content.protection: one pad, landing zone is flat and it's a low route though
content.location: Central to left side of the upper terrace. About 25 feet to the right of Crimp City and Alligator Clip.

content.description: Super Clean Drill Hole Line
content.location: Just to the right of the boulder fall about in the middle of the wall

content.description: Start with great holds at the bottom and work your way up to a sloper crossover then big bump to the top. Watch rock quality, some feels weak.
content.location: Upper terrace to the right of Alligator Clip.

content.description: See picture for start and end. Start on the low ledge and feet up. Reach for the crimp and find a 2 finger pocket to lean on. Grab the next ledge. The rest is pretty easy.
content.location: Same area as crimp city, but it goes left to right. See picture.

content.description: The boulder starts once youâre in the bat hang position. All rock below the ledge is off for feet and hands expect the initial starting hand tap. Crux is either getting out of the bat hang or getting to the third hold.
content.protection: One crash pad directly below the ledge
content.location: Main wall in the parking lot, to the right of Parvus

content.description: Solid face with pockets and crimps for hands, and a crux with feet on a small half moon shaped slab.   Starts with both hands on crimps and right foot on a small ledge. Left hand goes up to one of 2 good holds, and your right foot moves to the slab. Work your right hand up to the small pocket in a layback move, then power on up to the top 2 great holds. From here it's easy to work feet over to a large ledge to the left, it's a good place to rest as you don't really top, then just drop to the pad
content.location: Below the tallest evergreen on the lower terrace, a ways left of "When in Doubt" and "Parvus"

content.description: A compressed traverse sure to challenge the lankier among us, but no cakewalk for shorter climbers either. Start with two hands on the obvious crack, then work your way right staying under the low ledge - feet anywhere you want, but no hands above the roof. Avoid touching the loose rock in the center of the traverse, as it is unstable/unsafe, but the horizontal crack to the right of the loose rock is good once dusted off, and there is one good pinch just under the roof. One option is to mantle the roof in a classy "waiter" move. Finish with two hands on the low sloper around the corner. Roll off to dismount!
content.location: On the face parallel to the parking lot, nearest to the entrance. The route crosses under the low roof resembling a shallow cave.

content.description: Start on large belay ledge, climbs up to two other ledges at lower than 5.8 then to a finger crack roof crux
content.location: Far Left side of top quarry

content.description: Start almost directly beneath the old bolts. Climb up, and start heading to the left. There should be, near the end, an edge, another one after that, then a set of two crimps. The finish hold is an edge up and to the left of those crimps, about three feet to the left of the highest old bolt, the one with an orange loop through it.
content.protection: I'd place the pad two feet to the left of the starting hold.
content.location: The route is to the left of the upper terrace. There are two very visible old rusted bolts and a third one hiding. These are more or less above the start of the route.

content.description: Thin Finger Crack runs 1/3 of the way up, turning into a reaching crux for 1/3, last 1/3 is loose stone nub holds to the top-out.null
content.location: Toward the center/right side from the bottom, runs up a drill hole

content.description: Start with two hands on the bomber ledge and work your way to the left using the smaller aretes. Follow them back right again and finish just above where the crack starts.
content.location: Immediately to the right of crimp city on the upper terrace.

content.description: An old, abandoned quarry turned into a park in one of the nicest neighborhoods of Madison, WI yields plenty of potential for prime bouldering. The rock is mostly sandstone, with some dolomite. The sandstone parts are strong enough to hold on to. The area is mostly visited by people out for a short stroll and the neighborhood kids. Seldom is it frequented by climbers. There is an upper terrace and a lower terrace; the lower is very sunny, while the upper is quite shaded. Plenty of climbable area.
